Definition: Given a sentence, your responsibility is to classify it into two different classes, which are insult and non-insult. Classify as an insult if the sentence expresses any language that is rude or abusive.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: No wonder Hillary got beat by a circus clown.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is scornful and disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: I guess when you're clueless you stick your head into every hole.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is non-insult because it does not disrespect any group.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Hillary Clinton was not my girlfriend.

I did not have sexual relations with that woman.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be obscene but not insult.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: She is weak and useless, time to run her off
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is insult because it is disrespectful.

Comment: No, I am really not. Philosophy - from the Greek "philos' meaning love and "sophos" meaning "Wisdom", the love of wisdom - is literally the study of how to think straight.

If you haven't learned philosophy, you will never be able to form a logical thought. No, what people think they are doing isn't logic. Logic is a set of rules. To think logically you have to know those rules, and apply those rules (much like algebra is a set of rules you have to know and apply to get the right answer).

To think you can be logical without studying philosophy is like claiming you can do algebra without learning to count first. 

Here's how it works:
Philosophers figure out how to understand things.
Scientists use those techniques to understand a particular thing.
Engineers use that understanding to solve practical problems.

Unfortunately - because true logic is so often counter-intuitive, those not schooled in it tend to think actual logical arguments are "stupid" because their intuition says so.

Comment: The author gives a fair description of how the Russian Candidte negotiates. However, he misses one critical element. The RC is not driving his own car. In fact none of his money is on the line.

For our part we have a lot to lose, too. But if RC gets his way we lose regardless we strike a new deal or not. I think the US negotiators know this. I think they will look for a way to make a deal that looks like a win for the RC while leaving the essentials of NAFTA intact. Comment: What I really don't understand about the rational behind making gun control one of the major platforms for half of the country is that it is not the best use of the limited resource that is our national attention span.  

I don't disagree that the country needs to find a way to curb violent homicides, assaults and accidental death, but taking away guns isn't where we can do the most good - not even slightly.

Guns were involved in 1.3% of all deaths in 2013 - that included 11,208 by homicide, 21,175 by suicide and 505 in cases like this, accidental shootings.  

100% of the deaths by suicide could potentially have been prevented by better mental health care and probably 75-80% of the homicides could have been prevented if the perpetrators had better economic opportunities.

Meanwhile heart disease took 611,105 people, cancer 584,881, respiratory diseases 149,205, mechanical accidents and drowning  130,052, and strokes killed 128,978. Being unhealthy, stupid and smoking are the issues.

Comment: Democracy is great when your side wins. Otherwise, we use Mencken's worn quote to talk about the stupidity of the voters on the other side. Today's word of the day: trite.

Shrugging our collective shoulders and giving up isn't really an option.

Comment: Some malware does sit quietly in an attempt to get backed up, but this is rare for ransom attacks. But yes, this is something to be aware of.  Fortunately, it's fairly easy to defend against during the restore process when you have advance warning that it may be present. So backups are still effective, but people might want to get some professional assistance when recovering from an attack.

Uninstalling flash is a great security practice, but people shouldn't think that doing so means that they can relax. Most newer active malware these days don't use flash as the attack vector.

Comment: Perhaps government could subsidize just the regulatory part.  For example, the business license, the property taxes, and other "government"-related expenses for running a business.   Bill it more like a non-profit, to help it keep up with the tricky nature of daycare.  (The business model of potentially unlimited sales and thus profit doesn't apply, and every hour spent at daycare competes for an hour of the parents' wages.)  People have to be careful about looking at the entire cost of daycare as a singular expense.  Part of that cost is just covering supplies for the daycare, which a parent would be buying anyway if they were at home.  What the daycare spends on food, for example, is what the parent would have spent to feed the kid themselves if they were home, and bulk pricing might actually make some of those things relatively cheaper in a daycare setting.  So really it's only the daycare staff salaries we should consider an economically tricky expense.

Comment: Robin Brena has a plan
https://www.adn.com/opinions/2016/10/01/alaska-needs-to-reclaim-its-fair-share-of-oil-revenue/


(1) Increase the base rate for the major legacy fields and for merely harvesting our resources rather than exploring for additional resource.

(2) Eliminate credits (taken as deductions and paid) for all but the most challenged fields.

(3) Eliminate loss carryforwards.

(4) Eliminate the "new oil" definition or reduce the scope of its application to only the most challenged fields (which would not include Point Thomson).

(5) Increase progressivity.

(6) Add the auditing and legal resources necessary to ensure revenue certainty for the state and producers and to minimize gaming.

(7) Increase transparency so we know the financial performance of the producers operating in Alaska.

Comment: Some interesting issues.  Remember 1964 with Goldwater's campaign "you can't legislate morality".  It was a "code" opposition to the Civil Rights Act.  I have a very different take.  IMO, We should, in fact, be passing legislation which reflects morality.  The issue, of course, is "just what is morality."  Certainly the Civil Rights Act represented a statement of morality.  ..a statement of what is "right" and what is "wrong" in terms of treating other people.  

The issue of abortion is far less clear. Some see it as an immoral act which should be outlawed.  On the "flip side", a majority of  Americans see it as a woman's decision..her Choice and a reflection of her own personal morality.  So the key issue really surrounds just how much freedom of personal morality does a society allow?  Just when is the society justified in saying "sorry, no, that action (whatever it might be) is beyond the scope of personal moral choice is is now a "legal" issue?  Tough question.  regards, Gary Crum

The politicians running the country are playing with my money too, and they directly impact part of my pension.  My children and grandchildren live there and I follow Canadian news far closer than many (perhaps most) Canadians and deeply care about my homeland.  The decisions of these men and women I can't elect impact my family as they do me and I care.  Does the current fight over medicare impact me directly? NO, but it sure affects my grandchildren, and that is something I think is worth fighting about.

I know of no other country in the world that does something as stupidly outrageous as stealing the right to vote from it's citizens.  Certainly no country Canada wants to be compared to would do so.

Comment: I don't think you understand how Social Security works. 

We spend our whole lives paying into Social Security. When we retire, or if we are disabled in life, then we withdraw. It's not a handout the young are paying to the old. It's getting back the money that you have already put in. 

YES, it's being used, not just sitting in a vault---but the amount coming in isn't the same as what is going out. Same thing with your taxes and refunds. That money is used by the government---often in investments. It's a free loan we are all giving to our government, expecting to be paid back. 

Given that, it's up to the government to figure out how to pay us back, rather than just blowing it all. Of course, governments seem to be very bad at this.

Comment: Assumption always made is that a mutual fund is going to have the performance of an index or worse - simply not the case. When markets are virtually at all time highs - it is easy to make the case for the best index as it is really a growth equity mutual fund with no downside support. Watch what happens when markets go down. We have seen a couple of small examples where large ETF's have had horrible trading days. The market makers were not there. We'll see what happens when it gets real ugly. Also it has  not been difficult to outperform the TSX for the last 5 or 10 year time period. Many Canadian based mutual funds have outperformed their respective TSX index. However that wasn't the case during commodity bull run of 2001 -2008. Bond funds are another example of outperformance. I cannot recall anyone going through the last big downturn saying boy I wished I had an index fund. They were upset on both accounts but one generally outperformed the other - unless you were buying the losers.

Comment: Randy,
Thank you for asking, an excellent question and a foundation to scientific study.

You asked for my one best study?  
Too often people ask for "the study" which. . . . . 

That's not how science works, unless we are talking about simple math, you know, 2+2=4.  That simplicity makes life so simple.  

There is really no "one" study which is conclusive on any scientific subject, especially fluoride exposure.

We have a number of "streams" of evidence which become a river and then flow into the ocean of evidence.  Only then can we make a "judgment" based on all the evidence. 

Consider jurisdiction.  EPA? FDA? CDC? ADA? HHS?  What does the law say?
Consider dosage.  What is the range of fluoride exposure in the public at large?  What is desired? What is the difference?  Has that changed? And how much is too much?

Those two streams are just the start of good scientific exploration.

Comment: I must admit to being disappointed with this article.  The headline needlessly detracted from an outstanding local achievement.

The FDA conducted a thorough audit of all aspects of the Blood Bank of Alaska's activities - and gave the organization a completely clean bill of health:  no observations, no comments of concern, nothing.

The FDA looked at everything.  The FDA found nothing.  You can't ask for better than that.  

This is an important outcome for Alaska as the Blood Bank of Alaska is our blood bank. If you need, or if someone you know needs, to receive blood or blood products here in Alaska for whatever reason, that blood will almost certainly come from an Alaskan donor via the Blood Bank of Alaska.

A completely clean FDA Audit is almost unheard of in blood banking.  It is good news for Alaska's hospitals and clinics, it is good news for Alaskan patients, and it reflects really really well on everyone working at the Blood Bank.

Comment: My only objections are... 1. High price of new vinyl these days... $40-$60 for most albums.  2.  Vinyl works best with analog recordings.  Most all recordings these days are digital for the extra loud earbud generation, meaning most of any new album available on album is the digital equivalent.  You aren't going to get a better sounding digital recording than a CD.  Analog tends to sound more like the performance occurring in your living room when recorded on vinyl.  If you're getting a remaster, is it using the analog tapes?  3. Song skips.  Most albums are filled with some throw-aways.  The local record store in these parts has lots of vinyl on display, but lo and behold, there's a digital playlist on the speakers for a reason.

I really like the album art and booklets that would come with an LP.  Everything else? I'd rather forget.

Comment: With these few examples - one can draw a conclusion that the visual media (TV) vs. the 'printed' or electronic kind are having issues of content.  The 'printed' kind has a tendency to be more fact-filled, and in less need of having their viewers believe they are the sole-source for a story.  The visual people simplify, and are not capable of telling a story with too any moving parts (due to time constraints and advertising pressures?).  They do sound-bite journalism.  The consolidation of the media, visually speaking, has radically reduced news content and in turn made it easier, and almost 'justified' in 'borrowing' stories, and making no effort to acknowledge how they found them.  In this stew, its almost obligatory to omit a lot of data.  I lament the continued decline of critical, well thought-out journalism, and feel strongly that this lack of attribution only serves to enforce shoddy and inaccurate news reporting.

Comment: rgm,

Don't mean to pile on here, but there are things you need to know.  

First, cops, on average, miss their targets more often than not.  Off the top of my head there is a RAND corporation evaluation of NYPD shootouts that found officers missed their targets four out of five (!) times.  If suspects were unarmed or did not return fire results were better, but they still missed far more than half the time.  Bear in mind these NYPD officers were all trying to immediately stop or immobilize a suspect; in other words, they were likely trying to put bullets into vital organs or the central nervous system - which means the torso or the head.  Yet, most of their bullets went astray to endanger innocent bystanders.

A little vignette:  two SIG Sauer P226 armed cops, each with 16 9mm rounds on tap, both fired upon the same suspect.  Both officers were standing nearly side-by-side.  The rookie, who always had the P226 missed all (!) 16.  His partner, an old revolver hand, did not with his 6.

Comment: NYT: The White House said that Mr. Trump did not know that Mr. Flynn was acting as a foreign agent when Mr. Trump appointed him national security adviser, a position that gave him access to classified meetings and materials. But a person briefed on the matter, who insisted on anonymity to describe private conversations, said Mr. Flynn’s lawyer contacted a lawyer for Mr. Trump’s transition team before the inauguration to ask whether Mr. Flynn should register given his work for Inovo.

The transition lawyer offered no advice, saying it was up to Mr. Flynn. After the inauguration, the person said, Mr. Flynn and his lawyer each raised it again with a White House lawyer, only to be told once more it was up to him. Mr. Flynn had no comment on Friday. His lawyer wrote the Justice Department that Mr. Flynn decided to register retroactively “to eliminate any potential doubt.”

 Here's the thing, when teens want to alter their state of consciousness, and they can't get weed, they attempt to get alcohol, or pills, solvents or something else. Cannabis is an economic substitute for alcohol and other drugs such an fentanyl. Comment: In hindsight of course I now wish UH woulda, shoudla, coulda gone for it, after knowing the final outcome.  However, Rolovich did not have that luxury of knowing Brown's pass would tipped at the line of scrimmage and then intercepted when they got into the red zone in OT. As the clock was winding down late in the fourth quarter in regulation, I must admit that I agreed with the coaches decision to let the clock expire and try to beat them in overtime as they had only 38 seconds to move the ball 50 yards to get into field goal range, which translates to running two plays, most likely a pair of rushed long passes which could have resulted in a turnover, even a pick-six. The risk, was too great, for even if the Warriors did miraculously march the ball downfield 50 yards in less than 40 seconds, their field goal unit is far from automatic--kicker Ryan Meskell is 0-for-2 from beyond 30 yards this season. Thus I refuse to second guess Rolovich's decision to run out the clock. Go Warriors!

Comment: More false claims from James.

1.  The only dental fluorosis which may be attributable to fluoridated water is mild to very mild, a barely detectable effect which causes no adversity on cosmetics, form, function, or health of teeth.  This level of dental fluorosis is neither "enamel damage" nor does it require any treatment whatsoever.

2.  The "41% of all children" is a complete misrepresentation of a 2010 CDC study by Beltran-Aguilar in which 41% of adolescents examined showed signs of dental fluorosis.  This consisted of 37.1% with mild dental fluorosis, 3.8% moderate, and negligible severe, with the moderate being attributable  to improper ingestion of toothpaste, and/or exposure to high levels of environmental or well-water fluoride during teeth developing years of 0-8.

As can be seen, James provides yet further example of the dishonesty which is rife amongst antifluoridationists.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: You want suggestions for how Israel should deal with acts of terrorism? Simple. 

Israel should deal with acts of terrorism IN A LAWFUL WAY. There should be no violation of anyone's rights while doing so. And in particular, the rights of innocent people should never be violated in retaliation for the terrorism.

Israel destroys the home of a Palestinian if he commits an act of terrorism. Israel does not destroy the home of an Israeli if he commits an act of terrorism, of which there have been many. That's a violation of the principle of equality before the law.

Likewise, when Israel punishes an entire town for the transgression of a single individual, it's a reprisal. A war crime. Like other civilized nations, Israel should deal with terrorism in a way that doesn't violate international law and universal human rights.

Comment: The federal department of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC) spends $8,578 per year on every First Nations individual  in the country.
-
Over the past 60 years, INAC has given $215 billion to First Nations. Health Canada has given another $41 billion. That is only  two departments. There are nearly 30 federal departments and agencies that give money to aboriginal Canadians. Together, all federal spending on First Nations and First Peoples is closer to $13,000 per capita.
-
The entire federal budget for non-aboriginal persons is $7,295 each per year. That means Ottawa spends about 75% more for every aboriginal citizen than it spends on non-aboriginals.
-
Since 1994, total provincial spending has risen 31% after adjusting for inflation and populations growth. Over that same period, provincial spending on First Peoples has increased  by 1,235%.
-
Quebec and the First Nations - Canadas two great fiscal blast furnaces
Billions go in - and nothing but hot air and smoke comes out.

Comment: There are many unique aspects and special features to Taiwan's history and relationship with Mainland China and the following comments are not judgments regarding the equity or merits of that relationship; only the propriety of the US inserting the issue as its trade negotiations ploy.

Essentially, an implied understanding now exists between the Taiwanese and Mainland Governments concerning their relationship. That understanding is that the formalities of an overarching Chinese national unity will be respected but the day-to-day independence of Taiwan respected.  Both Governments, however, implicitly retain the right within limits to try to push that relationship to its advantage.

Given how fraught and fragile those understandings are, it is the height of irresponsibility for the US to threaten interference simply as a trade ploy.  It's as though the US were to threaten to raise questions about Canadian unity as a ploy in renegotiating NAFTA.

Comment: Full Senate reform (ie., changing its appointment process, its powers, the number of Senators etc.) would require an agreement to be passed by the federal parliament and all ten provincial legislatures within the space of three years.   So whether you consider that "difficult" or "impossible" depends on whether you think the federal government and provinces can compromise, come to an agreement and implement it.

I think what people really mean is that it is impossible to discuss Senate reform in Canada without opening up a can of worms about western alienation, Quebec's place in Canada, and all of the hard feelings between Canadians that existed in the early 1990s.  I'm not so sure that's true (or at least not true anymore); surely in 2016 we can have a rational debate about getting rid of an unelected body that represents nobody, spends a lot and has very little output, without stomping on each other's provincial flags.

Comment: From his 1974 book perhaps something every one of our representatives should consider when they believe they know better than I do, with the money I earn. "The root facts here are the incommensurability and incomplete communicability of human wants and values.  George Bernard Shaw long ago observed, “Do not do unto others as you would have them do unto you.  They may have different tastes.”  Social good, as in the determination of a just income distribution, is an abstraction of some kind from the individual values of the members of the society.  But this abstraction can only be based on interpersonally observed behavior, as in market purchases or voting, not on the full range of an individual’s feelings.  As is by now well known, attempts to form social judgments by aggregating individual expressed preferences always lead to the possibility of paradox.

Thus there cannot be a completely consistent meaning to collective rationality."
Thank you Sir

You don't think taking the vacant park blocks and giving people downtown a reason to go there on a regular basis won't transform the crowd from groups of homeless kids to groups of workers and residents? 

You don't think putting in some kind of high-traffic retail store where the empty downtown LCC building is would transform it from a trash-infested place where people sleep and loiter all day?

Yes, Eugene has a unique homeless problem and some people need help and shelter. But our downtown space has a lot of reasons for people not to spend time in it. And street kids and homeless fill that void. 

These measures are actually wise ways to solve it.

Comment: In the movie "Hoosiers" there is a scene in which one of the basketball players from the tiny rural school reads an essay to the class, something not done anymore because someone's self-esteem might suffer, on "Progress."   One of the things defined as progress is "school consolidation.   When I started grade school in '55 there were still schools in most of the "12 mile" towns in my county and several of them included high school.   By the time I graduated there was one school in my county, the one in the larger, county seat town.   It was traumatic for the people in the small towns to give up their schools to consolidation, but the one big school was much better except for the bus rides.   And yes, the towns have all but died as well; nothing left but the dead and dying in my little town.   There are over 1000 counties in the US with fewer people in 2010 than they had in 1910; rural Alaska shouldn't be exempt, and the rest of us shouldn't have to pay for the exemption.

Comment: About the only good thing one can say about the CPP system is that it isn't as much of a disaster as most other government pension plans in other countries around the world.

There are a number of things that CPP gets "right", but there are a LOT of things that CPP gets "wrong" to "very wrong".  A lot of this is due to historical baggage.  CPP, as it was originally designed in 1965, was a DISASTER!  It was a horrible system to start with and, rather than fixing things in the late 60's or through the 1970's, it was actually made worse.

Fortunately we have been fixing some of the mistakes of CPP for the past 20 years now, starting with a major overhaul in 1996/97 and continuing through to the changes made in ~2012/13.  Unfortunately there was a BIG hill to climb.

Comment: I believe we have made considerable progress against intellectual racism over the past century, but not against primal racism.  We will never overcome primal racism because it is part of our basic nature.  So in this increasingly crowded planet, if we are going to live together and not die together, we need to learn to live with people who may have different cultural attributes, and who may say or believe things that we do not like.  The best way to accomplish that would be to preserve sufficient space for people of different groups, and not force them to live on top of each other.  Diversity is not strength, it is a potential source of social tension.  People seem to know that instinctively and tend to live in their own communities.  We have seen that pattern in Canada's experiment in multiculturalism, that we have created many disparate ethnic/social groupings of people in mini-monocultures.  Inter-racial marriages are still quite uncommon, even in Toronto and Vancouver.

Comment: Two events at Dalhousie are interesting to compare.

In the first, a few years ago, feelings were hurt of a small group of women dentistry students, to do with the women complaining about what some male dentistry students had written on a password-protected chat site.

The response of the Globe and Mail, CBC and Toronto Star was swift and, within weeks, about a hundred outraged articles and opinion pieces and columns and editorials were given prominent page space.

In the second, a young man, student at Dalhousie, was murdered by a Dalhousie medical student, the man being a business acquaintance of the student.

Men in North America are three times more likely to be murdered than women.

And yet the murder of the student led to only a small handful of straight news reports, ending today with the guilty verdict. No stream of columns expressing concern about men being slaughtered much more often than women.

To media, value of a few women's hurt feelings trumps value of life of a man?

Comment: I'm white. I got a bogus speeding ticket 2 1/2 years ago from the chief of police in a small town in Kansas who was said to write tickets on non-residents to raise money. My ticket had been started before I ever got to town and the location and the speed limit were crudely changed on the ticket to make it appear genuine. The City Attorney who prosecuted it blocked my attempts to get a dash cam video and audio dispatch recording that would have proved the chief tampered with the evidence, writing the ticket to cover his failure to follow through with finishing for the person for whom he had been citing. I finally pleaded guilty to what I thought was a non-moving violation, rather than drive hundreds of miles again for a preliminary hearing and then a trial. However the prosecutor had lied to me. I actually got a moving violation.  I was appalled, but I must say that most of the police I've worked with over the years have been honest.  but am well aware judicial discrimination exists.

Comment: The U.S. has given Africa tens of billions of dollars every year. However, we might ask ourselves whether it’s foreign aid that Africa needs most for economic development. This myth holds that poor countries are poor because income is so low that savings cannot be generated to provide the kind of capital accumulation necessary for economic growth. Thus, it is alleged, the only way out of perpetual poverty is foreign aid.  And with foreign aid, what we created is a dependency continent.   Capitalism is the cure for Africa’s problems  not tribalism and foreign aid.    Confucius knew this  5000 years ago,

Comment: As a man, it strikes me as more than a little strange that so many voices would complain about the police conducting a thorough review of sexual assault complaints and procedures. Or perhaps it isn't strange at all, and that there's actually a straightforward explanation for that outcry.

The facts:

1. About 65% of all sexual assault victims are children or youths under the age of 17.

2. The vast majority of sexual assaults- 80%- occur in the victim's home.

3. The vast majority- 80%-  of the perpetrators are known to the victims.

Comment: I grew up in Portland and in 1992 I called Katherine Dunn to ask if she would speak at my high school's graduation. Her name was in the phone book, and she answered her own phone, which seemed as miraculous to me -- a huge fan of Geek Love -- as getting Philip Roth or Harper Lee on the phone. I don't remember our conversation in detail, but I do remember that she was warm, friendly, and seemed genuinely touched that my graduating class wanted her to speak at our graduation. Sadly, she was going to be out of the country on the date, so we wound up with another speaker, but I feel fortunate to have had the chance to interact with such a great Portlander. I cherish my signed copy of Geek Love. Rest in peace.

Comment: Followup:  For people under 65 (not on Medicare), the average annual health care cost is about $4,000, quite manageable with an HSA that pays the provider at point of sale with no claims processing.  It also brings competition into the picture, because it's your money you're spending and now care what the charges are.

50% of the claims are incurred by 5% of the people.  These are the "big claims," the unexpected and catastrophic, which would be the only claims "insured" with a major medical policy that has a $10,000 deductible.  You can pay the low premiums for it out of your HSA.

The other 50% of the claims incurred by 95% of the people amount to much less than $3,000 per year, so the HSA account balances for most people putting $250/mo into their HSA will grow.

We would still have to subsidize the HSAs for the poor, but it would be nice if we were only having to subsidize 40% to 50% lower costs, which HSAs would provide.  There would be more doctors accepting HSAs than Medicaid.

Comment: The idea behind the RRSP is that you defer tax until after retirement, at which point you are in a lower tax bracket.

But for many people who spend their entire lives in a lower tax bracket, an RRSP can be a bad idea.  For these people, withdrawing funds from an RRSP can reduce eligibility for programs like GIS.

Comment: Tad naive to complain that Kinder Morgan's $1bn fee to BC Gov't set a terrible precedent. Canadian politics is rife with these shakedown payments. In Ontario, the provincial Planning Act's Section 37 stipulates that real estate developers pay arbitrary funds into a discretionary pool controlled by the local councillor . . the negotiation of the amount and use of these Section 37 funds "buys" a councillor's support, generally to override the municipal city plan, that permits a huge new development to proceed, to the chief planner's and residents' eternal frustration. The fact that big shakedowns now happen for resource developments comes as no surprise . . .  Canadians don't live in the squeaky clean world we pretend to, its a banana republic out there.

That being said, while most cases of solitary confinement are unnecessary, some are.  Some serious offenders are isolated because they are either a threat to others in the general prison population or they may be threatened by the general prison population. In those cases that last beyond two weeks, officials should be required to justify the reasons for putting a prisoner into solitary confinement.

Comment: The people at the Denver Post ought to be smart enough to figure out this comment system makes them look both foolish and dishonest. They solicit a judgement call from their readers then sometimes penalize them for being "biased" in some unspecified way. I receive notifications of replies to comments of mine and some of these replies hardly seem to violate any reasonable standards, yet these comments sometimes mysteriously don't appear, making it look to the writer that I complained or flagged the comment in some way. On the other hand, many spiteful, untrue and rude comments do appear, making the script-driven software look amateurish and the invisible string-pullers at the Post look biased themselves. The Post can either publish or not publish my comments, it's their prerogative. The NY Times prints about 99% of my comments, no jumping through hoops required. There's a very limited amount of silly games I'm willing to play; commenting is more important to the Post than it is to me.

Comment: A second thought: could it be that this whole heated and emotional controversy stems from a simple linguistic misunderstanding? In English the word 'rape' has two related but distinct meanings, which, as far as I know isn't the case in other SA languages. It's commonly used with the meaning of to 'seize' or 'plunder' or 'lay waste'. One of the definitions of 'rape' in the Oxford dictionary is 'the wanton destruction or spoiling of a place' as in ‘the rape of the countryside’. Zapiro's cartoons conflate the two meanings: he's making a pun - and a particularly powerful one - not drawing an analogy. Looks to me like we're simply talking at cross purposes.

Comment: Boots, your comment that “They have refused to do their job and the president has had to just do it” is exactly what is wrong with the thinking of many people in America.  You and others like you either do not know or don’t give a rat’s arse about a document called the Constitution of the United States which establishes the separation of powers into three branches of government, legislative, executive and judiciary, and defines the roles of each.  The legislative branch (Congress) is responsible for making and changing laws; the executive (the President) is responsible for faithfully executing the laws and the judiciary (the courts) for interpreting laws.  If Congress does not pass a law requested by the President, so be it.  He cannot then “just do it” with an Executive Order as you seem to think. It is hard to believe that Civics 101 has to be explain to people who comment in this forum, but it appears to be the America in which we now live.

Comment: Both Trump and this column are incorrect about the provisions of the ACA. It does not apply to adult "children left [or living] at home." The ACA applies to adult children under age 26. They don't have to be living at home. They can be married and have kids. I know because I have 3 adult children between 21 and 25 living on their own and working low-wage jobs. One is the father of two children. They'd have no health insurance without the ACA's provision that they can stay on my plan. Check out the facts here: https://www.healthcare.gov/young-adults/children-under-26/

Prior to the ACA, the $8k my family spent annually was a one-time-use policy, since if we actually needed to use it it would have been canceled at the end of the year. Great for traffic crashes and quick-treatment cancers like Hodgkin's, but not so great for things like breast cancer.

Comment: Before blasting coding, at the kindergarten level and primary grades, what is coding? It is nothing more than a series of steps that can be repeated to create a pattern, with a predictable result. Examples include working with pattern blocks, cube links, simple games of position. Coding is a language and the reason we teach it is to give students the flexibility of getting inside the language, the framework of thought. It is NOT about programming as an end goal. BTW, all the educational  performance data supports coding. Nevertheless, life in any science (social and technical) is about creating/observing predictable patterns and testing them out. You will notice that young children do this instinctively anyway. They are constantly assessing, testing, repeating, modifying, retesting. Clearly this opinion is based on very narrow interpretations of coding with little understanding of its use and value in the classroom.

Comment: You're right, I'm ignoring all kinds of costs of building roads. For instance, freeway construction led to the collapse of urban centers, contributing to poverty and crime; asthma and related ailments are far more common near major roadways; expanding the right-of-way to make room for more lanes steals private property from landowners; tens of thousands of people die every year. 

If we're going to calculate the true costs of our roads, we should make sure we include everything from weather-related repairs to loss of mobility for the blind to property damage from drunks careening into houses. Then we can figure out who is responsible for those costs and allocate taxes and fees accordingly.

Most studies that look at the economics of transportation agree that cycling investments result in a net gain for governments, while the true costs of car use extend vastly beyond the narrow focus on infrastructure. I don't think you'd be happy to see that reflected in the gas tax.

Comment: Wagner's initial order was wrongheaded - as was MacLachlan's decision to void it in response to social media protests. 

Greater sensitivity should have been shown to the LGBT community when granting intervenor status. That said, I doubt any of the interventions will have a significant impact on the outcome of the appeal. No doubt the justices are already seized by the starkness of the underlying conflict between two competing protections under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. 

It was inevitable from the day the Charter was signed into law that the SOCC would be forced to adjudicate the inherent conflict between fundamental freedoms and equality rights - in this case between 2.(a) and 15.1. Its decisions thus far have tended to favour the former over the latter, but Trinity Western may force it to issue a much more direct, irrevocable declaration of their relative standing within the constitution.

Comment: I had a couple of tenants that have a pitbull mix. The dog has some serious separation anxiety, to the point that it would destroy just about any enclosure it was put in, from a camper to a steel kennel to trim and doors in a house. Because of this, the owners went online and got a certificate stating that it was an "emotional support dog" so that they could take this dog with them on an airline instead of kenneling it like any normal, responsible pet owner. When they moved to a new house, I know for a fact that they leveraged this "status" against their current landlord for the purpose of getting out of paying a pet deposit. If that all weren't bad enough of an abuse of an otherwise necessary system, this dog attacked the face of, without provocation, a docile 8 year girl, and came within 1/2" of taking out her eyeball with a canine tooth. I love dogs, and I never had anything against pitbulls...but now I get it, although I still think this situation is due to irresponsible owners.

Comment: Under assets are: Bank savings accounts $290,000; GICs $4,265;

I'm guessing she doesn't need that $290,000 right away, so why leave it parked in savings account where it earns little, if any, interest?  Violet is not a sophisticated investor, so I'll recommend something I wouldn't do myself, but which will work for an unsophisticated investor like Violet.

Take some of the $290,000 and park it in a GIC or three.  In fact, put it into a GIC ladder.  Say, $20,000 to $40,000 in each of a one year, two year, three year, four year and five year non-cashable GIC.  The exact amounts should be based on her plans and financial needs for the next three to five years.

It's not going to protect from inflation, but it will give a small return that is better than what she would get in a bank account.  And she won't get hit with exorbitant mutual fund fees either.

Comment: William and Monte,

I think part of the problem here, that you two are circling around but not closing-in on, is the offices and roles described in the Church Manual, do not fit well with the broader concept of Spiritual Gifts that you both espouse.  And pastors and nominating committees can become focused on recruiting people for jobs that are described in the Manual.  And do you simply shut-down certain ministries (eg youth activities) because nobody has the passion? Comment: JBob, you reference the Last Judgment in Mt 25.31ff. 

May I invite you to assist me in a little experiment here? I think everyone in our society, whether Christian or not, has a vivid image of the Last Judgement scene (Jesus sitting on his throne, sorting out the good on his right and the bad on his left) but we tend to mis-remember what Jesus said, what virtues and vices Jesus ascribed to the good and to the bad. If you are willing to be a data point in my ongoing survey, first please pause and write down the kind of activity you think Jesus lists as worthy of heaven and worthy of hell; and then go read the passage.

Comment: But given that a large part of undocumented immigration is due to people overstaying their initially legitimate visas (essentially deciding to not go home as required), the normal visa program has to remain closed, as it has been for a long time, to anyone who would have a high probability of benefitting from remaining in the US. 

Based on a government report issued in Feb. of last year, approximately 415,000 people whose visa was supposed to end in 2015 have decided to stay in the US. That's just for visas expiring in 2015. Presumably a similar story exists for every year. It adds up fast. 

This is a judgment call that State has to make on every visa application, and given they can't know what is in someone's head, they have to be convinced by objective data that the person would not benefit nor want to stay here as compared to returning home. 

This gentleman can't satisfy that criteria. So he doesn't get a visa. It's not political.

Comment: But the front range population, ultimately users of the same water, is increasing. Eastern plains problems are partially caused by entities like United Power, who can and will pay above market value, buying water shares from eastern plains farmers. That water then, thru share switching, ends up diverted to the front range and southern Colorado. Northern Water is going thru the long, laborious process of getting the Northern Integrated Supply Project (NISP) getting approved to avoid sending water beyond what is required by interstate compacts to surrounding states.  The project's intent is to keep surplus water here during the wet years, storing it for the dry ones.  But the Save The Poudre group, and others, have concerns, real or imagined, that have to be addressed. Farmers are often portrayed as buffoons with no concept of conservation. But I would argue most consider themselves stewards of the land and are the original conservationists.

Comment: Electric Utilities are low risk loan prospects for lenders, with corresponding low return expectations.

In this case NL put up nothing, but wants a return on the original Hydro Quebec Capital Cost that you would normally only expect from High Risk investments.

After a Business Disaster the priority is getting the generators, distribution capacity and plant management systems up and running, not the billing system. 

You can't go back and time and sell extra electricity to compensate for having to shut down a "steamer" because you lost track of the maintenance schedule and have to take it offline for more than the typical one month out of every three. You can always bill after the fact. Electric Utility Comptrollers would have no trouble getting short term financing to cover a billing gap of a month or two.
